name: Floating Bladderwort

Identifying Characteristics: Submersed aquatic plant; very delicate in appearance
Stems: medium length; branching; delicate; flaccid
Leaves: typically pale green, finely branch-divided, alternately arranged

Flowers: midsummer, yellow snapdragon-like; a single flower stalk (often with multiple flowers) emerges from an inflated ‘raft’ comprised of 4 - 7 air-filled leaves arranged in a whorl; floating leaves are flattened, elongate, and finely branched toward the tip
Other: carnivorous - tiny lopsided sack-like bladders (used to capture prey such as zooplankton or small insects) are attached directly to submersed leaves
Habitat: Lakes, ponds, slow moving streams, wetland pools
Range: Native Range: Maine, much of New England, some other parts of the United States

tags: plants with finely-divided leaves on stems
